questions.question: A 17-year-old dependent has $1,500 in wages and $600 in interest income. Must they file a tax return for 2024?

options.A: No—total income is below standard deduction

questions.explanation: Dependents must file if unearned income exceeds $1,300 (2024). Interest of $600 is under this threshold. However, total income must also be evaluated. For dependents, the filing threshold is the greater of $1,300 or earned income + $450, up to standard deduction.
questions.tip: Dependent filing: Unearned > $1,300, or earned > standard deduction triggers filing requirement.

questions.question: Which entity can be a shareholder of an S corporation?
questions.explanation: Eligible S corp shareholders include individuals, estates, certain trusts (grantor trusts, QSSTs, ESBTs), and tax-exempt organizations. C corporations, partnerships, and nonresident aliens cannot be S corp shareholders.
questions.tip: S corp eligible shareholders: Individuals, estates, qualifying trusts. No corps, partnerships, or NRAs.

questions.question: Under current law, Section 1031 like-kind exchange treatment is available for:

options.B: Real property held for business or investment only

questions.explanation: After TCJA (2018), Section 1031 applies only to real property held for productive use in trade or business or for investment. Personal property exchanges no longer qualify for tax deferral.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA Section 1031: Real property only. Personal property exchanges are taxable.

questions.question: A married taxpayer covered by an employer retirement plan wants to deduct a traditional IRA contribution. At what income level does the deduction begin to phase out for 2024 (MFJ)?
questions.explanation: For MFJ taxpayers where the contributing spouse is covered by a retirement plan, the traditional IRA deduction phases out at $123,000-$143,000 MAGI for 2024. If only the other spouse is covered, higher thresholds apply.
questions.tip: Traditional IRA phase-out (MFJ, covered by plan): $123K-$143K for 2024.

questions.question: What is the gift tax annual exclusion for 2024?
questions.explanation: The 2024 gift tax annual exclusion is $18,000 per donee. This allows unlimited recipients without using unified credit or filing gift tax returns (unless gift-splitting with spouse).
questions.tip: 2024 annual exclusion: $18,000 per donee. Indexed for inflation.

questions.question: The child tax credit begins to phase out for married filing jointly taxpayers when modified AGI exceeds:
questions.explanation: The child tax credit phases out at $400,000 for MFJ ($200,000 for all other filing statuses). The credit is reduced by $50 for each $1,000 (or part thereof) of MAGI over the threshold.
questions.tip: Child tax credit phase-out: $400K MFJ, $200K others. Reduces $50 per $1K over threshold.

questions.question: A partner's outside basis is $50,000. The partnership allocates $30,000 of income and makes a $20,000 cash distribution. What is the partner's ending basis?
questions.explanation: Beginning basis $50,000 + income allocation $30,000 = $80,000. Less distribution $20,000 = $60,000 ending basis. Income increases basis; distributions decrease basis (but not below zero).
questions.tip: Partner basis: + income, - losses, + contributions, - distributions. Cannot go below zero.

questions.question: What is the federal estate tax exemption (basic exclusion amount) for 2024?
questions.explanation: The 2024 basic exclusion amount is $13.61 million per individual (indexed). Married couples can shelter $27.22 million combined with portability. This amount is scheduled to drop significantly after 2025 under TCJA sunset.
questions.tip: 2024 estate exemption: $13.61M per person. Will decrease substantially after 2025.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells property with a $600,000 sales price and $200,000 basis for $100,000 down and $500,000 note. What gross profit percentage applies to each payment?
questions.explanation: Gross profit = $600,000 - $200,000 = $400,000. Gross profit percentage = $400,000 / $600,000 = 66.7%. This percentage applies to each principal payment (not interest) to determine recognized gain.
questions.tip: Installment sale: Gross profit % = Gain / Contract price. Applies to principal payments.

questions.question: A married filing jointly taxpayer has $400,000 in wages. How much additional Medicare tax (0.9%) is owed?
questions.explanation: The 0.9% additional Medicare tax applies to wages exceeding $250,000 for MFJ ($200,000 for single). Tax = ($400,000 - $250,000) × 0.9% = $150,000 × 0.9% = $1,350.
questions.tip: Additional Medicare tax: 0.9% on wages over $250K (MFJ) / $200K (single).

questions.question: Most states have moved to which apportionment formula for multistate businesses?
questions.explanation: Most states have adopted single sales factor apportionment, which bases taxable income solely on where sales occur. This benefits businesses with significant property and payroll in one state but sales in many states.
questions.tip: Single sales factor trend: Most states now. Benefits companies with operations concentrated in one state.

questions.question: Under Section 409A, when can deferred compensation be distributed without penalty?

options.B: Only upon specified events like separation from service, disability, or death

questions.explanation: Section 409A limits distributions to specified events: separation from service, disability, death, specified time or schedule, change in control, or unforeseeable emergency. Violation results in income inclusion plus 20% penalty.
questions.tip: 409A distributions: Only at specified events. 20% penalty + income inclusion for violations.

questions.question: A taxpayer expects significantly higher tax rates next year. Which year-end strategy is most beneficial?
questions.explanation: When expecting higher future rates, accelerate income into the current (lower rate) year and defer deductions to the future (higher rate) year. This maximizes the tax benefit of deductions and minimizes tax on income.
questions.tip: Rate changes: Accelerate income to low-rate years; defer deductions to high-rate years.

questions.question: A C corporation owns 25% of another domestic corporation and receives $100,000 in dividends. What is the dividends received deduction?
questions.explanation: DRD is 50% for less than 20% ownership, 65% for 20-79% ownership, and 100% for 80%+ ownership. With 25% ownership, the 65% DRD applies: $100,000 × 65% = $65,000 deduction.
questions.tip: DRD: <20% = 50%; 20-79% = 65%; 80%+ = 100%. Based on stock ownership percentage.

questions.question: Under SECURE Act 2.0, at what age must required minimum distributions begin for someone born in 1960?
questions.explanation: SECURE 2.0 changed RMD ages: 73 for those born 1951-1959, 75 for those born 1960 or later. The RMD beginning date is April 1 of the year following the year the participant turns the applicable age.
questions.tip: SECURE 2.0 RMD ages: Born 1951-59 = age 73; Born 1960+ = age 75.

questions.question: A partnership has inventory and substantially appreciated unrealized receivables. These are referred to as:
questions.explanation: Section 751 'hot' assets include unrealized receivables and substantially appreciated inventory. Sales or exchanges involving these assets convert what would be capital gain into ordinary income.
questions.tip: Hot assets (751): Inventory + unrealized receivables = ordinary income on sale/exchange.

questions.question: For research expenses to qualify for the Section 41 credit, the research must meet a four-part test. Which is NOT one of the requirements?
questions.explanation: The four-part test: (1) permitted purpose (new/improved function, performance, quality, reliability), (2) technological in nature, (3) elimination of uncertainty, (4) process of experimentation. U.S. location is a separate requirement, not part of the four-part test.
questions.tip: R&D four-part test: Purpose, technology, uncertainty, experimentation. U.S. location is separate.

questions.question: A beneficiary inherits stock with a decedent's basis of $100,000 and date of death FMV of $500,000. What is the beneficiary's basis?
questions.explanation: Inherited property generally receives a basis equal to fair market value at date of death (or alternate valuation date). The $400,000 of appreciation is never taxed due to the step-up.
questions.tip: Step-up at death: Basis = FMV. Unrealized gain escapes income tax entirely.

questions.question: An S corporation with no accumulated E&P distributes $100,000 to its sole shareholder with $60,000 stock basis. How is the distribution treated?

options.B: $60,000 tax-free return of basis; $40,000 capital gain

questions.explanation: With no E&P, distributions first reduce stock basis (tax-free) and then are treated as gain from sale of stock. $60,000 is return of basis, $40,000 excess is capital gain.
questions.tip: S corp distributions (no E&P): Tax-free to extent of basis; excess = capital gain.

questions.question: Under Section 163(j), business interest expense is generally limited to what percentage of adjusted taxable income?
questions.explanation: Section 163(j) limits the deduction for business interest expense to 30% of adjusted taxable income (ATI), plus floor plan financing interest and business interest income. Disallowed interest carries forward indefinitely.
questions.tip: Section 163(j): Business interest limited to 30% of ATI. Small business exemption applies.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells commercial real estate for $500,000 with an adjusted basis of $350,000. Of the $150,000 gain, $80,000 is attributable to accumulated depreciation. What is the depreciation recapture?
questions.explanation: For Section 1250 property (real estate), there is no ordinary income recapture for straight-line depreciation. However, unrecaptured Section 1250 gain (the depreciation portion) is taxed at a maximum 25% rate instead of the 20% LTCG rate.
questions.tip: Section 1250 recapture: Real estate straight-line = 25% max rate, not ordinary income.

questions.question: A gift to an irrevocable trust does not qualify for the annual exclusion unless:

options.A: The trust has only one beneficiary
options.B: Beneficiaries have a present interest through withdrawal rights (Crummey powers)
options.C: The gift is made in December

questions.explanation: Annual exclusion requires a present interest gift. Crummey powers give beneficiaries a temporary right to withdraw contributions, converting a future interest into a present interest and qualifying for the annual exclusion.
questions.tip: Crummey powers: Create present interest for annual exclusion on trust gifts.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells stock for a $10,000 loss and buys substantially identical stock 20 days later. What is the tax consequence?

options.B: Loss is disallowed and added to basis of new stock
options.D: Loss is deferred until the new stock is sold

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule disallows losses when substantially identical securities are purchased within 30 days before or after the sale. The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the replacement stock.
questions.tip: Wash sale: 30-day window. Disallowed loss → added to basis of replacement stock.

questions.question: A single taxpayer has $300,000 MAGI including $50,000 of net investment income. What is the NIIT liability?
questions.explanation: NIIT is 3.8% on the lesser of net investment income or MAGI over threshold ($200,000 single). MAGI over threshold = $100,000. Net investment income = $50,000. NIIT = 3.8% × $50,000 (lesser amount) = $1,900.
questions.tip: NIIT: 3.8% × lesser of (NII or MAGI over threshold). Thresholds: $250K MFJ, $200K single.

questions.question: A taxpayer contributes $50,000 to a donor advised fund in December. Grant recommendations to charities are made the following year. What is the 2024 charitable deduction?
questions.explanation: Charitable deductions for DAF contributions are taken in the year of contribution, not when grants are recommended. The contribution is irrevocable when made, qualifying for immediate deduction.
questions.tip: DAF deduction: Year of contribution. Immediate deduction, flexible grant timing.

questions.question: An LLC files Form 8832 to elect C corporation treatment. How far back can the election be effective?
questions.explanation: A check-the-box election can be effective up to 75 days before the election is filed, or up to 12 months after filing. This provides flexibility for late elections but has time limits.
questions.tip: Form 8832: Effective 75 days back or 12 months forward from filing date.

questions.question: A cash-basis taxpayer receives a check dated December 28, 2024. The taxpayer doesn't cash it until January 3, 2025. When is the income recognized?
questions.explanation: Under the constructive receipt doctrine, income is taxable when it's made available without substantial limitation. Receipt of a valid check constitutes constructive receipt regardless of when deposited, unless the check is postdated or subject to conditions.
questions.tip: Constructive receipt: Income taxable when available. Check received = income in that year.

questions.question: A calendar-year partner receives guaranteed payments from a fiscal-year partnership (year-end March 31). When does the partner report guaranteed payments made in April through December?

options.B: When the partnership's fiscal year ends

questions.explanation: Partners report their distributive share (including guaranteed payments) when the partnership year ends. Guaranteed payments from April-December are reported when the partnership's year ends in March of the following year.
questions.tip: Partnership items: Reported when partnership year ends, not when received. Year-end alignment matters.

questions.question: A 30% interest in a $10 million closely held business is valued for gift tax. Appraisers apply a 25% combined discount. What is the gift tax value?
questions.explanation: Undiscounted value = $10M × 30% = $3M. With 25% combined discount: $3M × (1 - 25%) = $3M × 75% = $2,250,000 gift tax value. Minority and marketability discounts can significantly reduce transfer values.
questions.tip: Valuation discounts: Minority + marketability can reduce values 20-40%+ combined.

questions.question: A C corporation converts to S status with $500,000 of net unrealized built-in gains. In year 3, the S corp sells an asset with $100,000 built-in gain. What is the BIG tax?
questions.explanation: Built-in gains recognized within 5 years of C-to-S conversion are subject to corporate-level tax at 21%. The tax applies to the lesser of recognized gain or net unrealized built-in gain. BIG tax = $100,000 × 21% = $21,000.
questions.tip: BIG tax: 21% corporate tax on gains within 5 years of C-to-S conversion.

questions.question: An executive receives restricted stock worth $100,000 (no cost) subject to 4-year vesting. What happens if an 83(b) election is made and the executive leaves after 2 years, forfeiting the stock?

options.A: No tax consequence—election eliminates all risk
options.C: No deduction allowed; tax paid on original inclusion is lost
options.D: Amended return to recover tax paid

questions.explanation: If stock is forfeited after an 83(b) election, no deduction is allowed for the forfeiture. The tax paid on the original inclusion is not recoverable. This is the risk of 83(b)—paying tax on property that may never vest.
questions.tip: 83(b) risk: Forfeiture = no deduction, no recovery of tax paid. Evaluate vesting likelihood.

questions.question: A taxpayer has excess foreign tax credits that cannot be used in the current year. What is the carryover period?
questions.explanation: Unused foreign tax credits can be carried back 1 year and forward 10 years. Credits are applied in chronological order (FIFO). The carryover period is shorter than NOLs (indefinite) or general business credits (1 back, 20 forward).
questions.tip: FTC carryover: 1 year back, 10 years forward. Applied in order earned (FIFO).

questions.question: A simple trust has DNI of $30,000 and distributes $40,000 to the beneficiary. How much is taxable to the beneficiary?
questions.explanation: Beneficiaries are taxed on the lesser of actual distributions or DNI. The trust cannot distribute more taxable income than it has (DNI). The beneficiary reports $30,000; the additional $10,000 is tax-free distribution of corpus.
questions.tip: Beneficiary income: Lesser of distribution or DNI. Excess = tax-free corpus distribution.

questions.question: A taxpayer with $500,000 taxable income has $200,000 QBI from a non-SSTB, but the business pays no W-2 wages and owns no qualified property. What is the Section 199A deduction?
questions.explanation: Above the threshold ($364,200 MFJ), the deduction is limited to the greater of: (1) 50% of W-2 wages, or (2) 25% of W-2 wages + 2.5% of qualified property. With no wages and no property, both limits are $0.
questions.tip: Above threshold: W-2 wages or property required for QBI deduction. Zero wages = zero deduction.

questions.question: In a Type A reorganization, target shareholders receive 60% stock and 40% cash. What are the tax consequences?

options.C: Tax-free for stock portion; boot triggers gain recognition up to realized gain

questions.explanation: Continuity of interest is met (40%+ stock). The stock received is tax-free. The cash 'boot' triggers gain recognition to the extent of realized gain. Loss is never recognized in reorganizations even with boot.
questions.tip: Reorg with boot: Stock = tax-free; boot = gain recognized (not exceeding realized gain).
